overview: Income Tax is a tax on income - find out about what it is, how you pay and how to check you're paying the right amount
title: Income Tax

table.body:
Income Tax is a tax you pay on your income. You don't have to pay tax on all types of income.

You pay tax on things like:

- money you earn from employment
- most pensions
- interest on savings
- rental income
- benefits you get from your job
- income from a trust

You don't pay tax on things like:

- income from tax-exempt accounts, like Individual Savings Accounts (ISAs)
- Working Tax Credit
- premium bond wins

^Get details about what types of income are [taxable and non-taxable](/taxable-income "taxable and non-taxable income"){:rel="external"} ^

##Income Tax allowances and reliefs

Most people in the UK get a ['Personal Allowance'](/income-tax-rates "Income Tax rates and allowances") of tax-free income. This is an amount of income you can have before you pay tax. If you're aged over 65, you may get a high tax-free allowance.

The amount of tax you pay can also be reduced by [tax reliefs](/tax-reliefs "Tax reliefs") if you qualify for them.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Pay As You Earn (PAYE)

Most people pay Income Tax through PAYE. This is the system your employer or pension provider uses to take Income Tax and National Insurance contributions before they pay your wages or pension.

##Self Assessment tax returns

If your financial affairs are more complex, like you're self employed or have a high income, you may pay Income Tax and National Insurance contributions through the [Self Assessment system.](/self-assessment-tax-returns "Self Assessment tax returns") You'll need to fill in a tax return every year.

##Income Tax on savings and investment interest

Income Tax is usually automatically taken from [interest on savings and investments.](/apply-tax-free-interest-on-savings "Tax on savings interest")

##Income that's not automatically taxed

If you get income that hasn't been taxed (eg rental income), you must tell HMRC.

If it's more than £2,500 or you don't pay tax through your wages or pension, you must tell HMRC by filling in a tax return. If you don't do this already, you must [register for Self Assessment.](/register-for-self-assessment "Register for Self Assessment")

If the untaxed income is less than £2,500, call HMRC.

table.title: How you pay Income Tax

table.body:
To work out if you should be paying Income Tax, follow these steps.

s1. Add up all your [taxable income.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/taxable-income.htm "taxable income"){:rel="external"}
s2. Work out your [tax-free allowances](/income-tax-rates 'tax-free allowances'). Your Personal Allowance and the Blind Person's Allowance (if applicable) will tell you how much you can earn before you have to pay tax.
s3. Take your tax-free allowances away from your taxable income.

After step 3, if there's anything left, you're a taxpayer and must [contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sf=&sp_scope=hmrc&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx0=49612 'contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)'){:rel="external"}  if you're not already paying tax.

If there's nothing left, you shouldn't be paying tax and may be [due a refund](/claim-a-tax-refund "Claim a tax refund")

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Should you be paying Income Tax?

table.body:
To find out if you're paying the right amount of Income Tax, use the [tax checker](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/stc.htm 'HMRC's tax checker'){:rel="external"} on the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website. 

You need to be:

- under 65
- a basic or higher rate tax payer
- getting the basic Personal Allowance

You can't use the tax checker if:

- you're entitled to claim [Married Couple's Allowance](/married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance")
- you're 65 or over and get age-related allowances
- your income is over £100,000
- you have other taxable income (eg from dividends and trusts)
- you get taxable State benefits
- you're self-employed

You also need details of:

- your total earnings for the tax year before tax was taken off
- the total tax paid on your earnings
- the interest from any savings after tax was taken off
- the total tax you paid on savings
- the total amount of any Gift Aid donations you've made

The tax checker will give you an estimate.

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
